title: 114_hr3785
content: The "Correcting Hurtful and Alienating Names in Government Expression (CHANGE) Act" is the short title of this Act. It aims to modernize language referring to individuals who are not citizens or nationals of the United States. An Executive agency shall not use the terms "alien" or "illegal alien" in any documents issued after the enactment of this Act, except when quoting external sources. SEC. 3. UNIFORM DEFINITION. Amends Chapter 1 of title 1, United States Code to define 'foreign national' as any individual other than a U.S. citizen or someone owing permanent allegiance to the U.S. SEC. 4. REFERENCES. In federal statutes, the term "alien" now refers to "foreign national" for non-citizens, and "illegal alien" now refers to "undocumented foreign national" for those unlawfully present or lacking legal immigration status. Amendments have been made to replace "illegal aliens" with "undocumented foreign nationals" in specific sections of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Amendments have been made in various federal statutes to replace the term "illegal aliens" with "undocumented foreign nationals" in specific sections. Amendments in federal statutes have replaced the term "illegal aliens" with "undocumented foreign nationals" in specific sections, including the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 and the Omnibus Consolidated Appropriations Act, 1997. Amendments in federal statutes have replaced the term "illegal aliens" with "undocumented foreign nationals" in various sections of different acts.
